questions.text: Which of the following was recommended by the Shrivatsav committee?
questions.solution:
The village health guide scheme was proposed by Shrivastav committee. 

Village health guide:

  • Guidelines for choosing VHG 
    • Person can be from either sex but must be resident of the village.
    • Person must know to read and write and have education up to 6th grade.
    • He/she must be able to spare around 2-3 hours a day for community work.
    • He/she must be acceptable to all parts of the community.
  • VHGs were trained for 2-3 months before beginning of work.
  • Norm was 1 VHG per 1000 population.

Other Options:

Option A: The health survey and development committee (or Bhore committee) started the 3 million plan. 

Option B: The integration of health services was proposed by Jungalwallah committee.

Option C: The multipurpose worker scheme was by Kartar Singh committee.

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image is magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy showing choline peak, which is diagnostic of glioma.

MR spectroscopy is a non-invasive means of obtaining metabolic information.

Increased choline reflects increased membrane synthesis and/or an increased number of cells, as seen in tumors. Choline is an important component of the cell membranes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of fetal biophysical profile?
questions.solution:
The contraction stress test is not a component of the biophysical profile.

Components of Biophysical profile (BPP)/Manning score:

(Mnemonic:BATMaN)

  • B - Breathing movements of the fetus
  • A - Amniotic fluid volume
  • T - Tone of the fetus
  • M - Movements of the fetus
  • N - Non-stress test (NST)

The modified biophysical score has only 2 components i.e NST and amniotic fluid index only. It is considered abnormal (nonreassuring) when the NST is non-reactive and/or the AFI is <5.

*Note: The contraction stress test (oxytocin challenge test) is an invasive method to assess fetal well-being during pregnancy. When there is an alteration in FHR in response to uterine contractions, it suggests fetal hypoxia.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about composting?

choices.text: Bangalore method is an aerobic process
Mechanical composting uses a controlled environment
Nightsoil can also be disposed with composting
Compost has few or no disease-causing pathogens

questions.solution:
The Bangalore method of composting is an anaerobic process.

Composting is a method of combined disposal of refuse and nightsoil. In this process, organic matter is broken down into compost. It has manure value and few or no disease-causing pathogens.

Bangalore method is an anaerobic method and is also called hot fermentation process. Trenches with a depth of not more than 90cm are used for this. This is done by spreading a layer of refuse (15 cm thick) at the bottom of the trench and nightsoil (5cm thick) is added next. Layers of refuse and nightsoil are added alternatively till the heap rises to 30cm above ground level. The heap is then covered with excavated earth. At the end of 4 – 6 months, decomposition will be completed.

Mechanical composting is an aerobic process. In this method, compost is manufactured on a large scale by processing raw materials and turning out a finished product. The refuse is first cleared of salvageable materials. It is then pulverised to reduce the size of particles to less than 2 inches. The pulverised refuse is then mixed with sewage, sludge or nightsoil in a rotating machine and incubated.

questions.text: Prolactinoma presents with ________
questions.solution:
Among the given options, bitemporal quadrantanopia is more likely to be seen in patients with prolactinoma.

The most commonly seen visual field defect is bitemporal hemianopia often more pronounced superiorly. It occurs because nasal ganglion cell fibers, which cross the optic chiasm, are especially vulnerable to compression of the ventral optic chiasm.

questions.text: Which type of hernia is depicted in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
The diagram shows Maydl’s hernia/ Hernia-en-W/ retrograde hernia, it has two small bowel loops within a single hernial sac forming a "W" shape. The center portion of the 'W' loop is strangulated and it lies within the abdominal cavity.

Option a: In Richter's hernia, a small portion of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped within the hernia. Strangulation can occur without the pres­ence of intestinal obstruction. Clinically, it mimics gastroenteritis.

Option b: In Littre’s hernia, Meckel’s diverticulum is the content.

Option c: In pantaloon hernia, both direct and indirect hernia occur on the same side.

questions.text: A child with recurrent urinary tract infection undergoes voiding cystourethrogram for the evaluation of vesicoureteric reflux (VUR). It shows the reflux of urine into the pelvis and calyces, without dilatation of the ureter. The grade of VUR is _____.
questions.solution:
Reflux of urine into pelvis and calyces without dilatation is Grade II vesicoureteric reflux (VUR).

VUR is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the upper urinary tract. VUR is a common clinical entity. The investigation of choice for VUR is micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).

VUR is graded as follows:

 GRADE DESCRIPTION
              I Reflux into a non-dilated ureter
             II Reflux into the pelvis and calyces without dilatation of the ureter
             III Reflux is associated with mild to moderate dilatation of the ureter, renal pelvis, and calyces, with minimal blunting of the fornices
             IV Moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilatation of the pelvis and calyces
              V Gross dilatation of the ureter, pelvis, and calyses; loss of papillary impressions; ureteral  tortuosity

questions.text: Which of the following is the endocrinological change of PCOD?
questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true regarding the endocrinological feature of PCOD.

Endocrine dysfunction includes the following: 

  • Insulin resistance 
  • impaired glucose tolerance and Type 2 diabetes mellitus 
  • Dyslipidemia: Increased LDL and triglyceride levels, elevated total cholesterol levels: High-density lipoprotein (HDL) ratios
  • Risk of endometrial cancer increased three-folds 
  • Infertility/subfertility 

Note: Mild elevations in testosterone levels are consistent with the diagnosis of PCOS. However, values > 200 ng/dL may suggest an ovarian tumour and warrant pelvic sonography.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient comes to the psychiatry outpatient department with complaints of low mood, difficulty falling asleep, lack of appetite, lack of energy, and recurring thoughts of death for the past 4 weeks. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The possible diagnosis in a patient with complaints of low mood, difficulty falling asleep, lack of appetite, lack of energy, and recurring thoughts of death for a period of 4 weeks is a major depressive disorder. 

Major depressive disorder is a mood disorder characterized by pervasive low mood without manic or hypomanic episodes. A major depressive episode lasts for at least two weeks and the patient experiences at least 4 of the following symptoms:

  • Feeling depressed/low mood for most of the day
  • Changes in appetite
  • Changes in weight
  • Changes in sleep
  • Changes in activity level
  • Lack of energy
  • Feelings of guilt
  • Recurring thoughts of death/suicidal thoughts

These symptoms usually cause significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Other options:

Option A: Conversion disorder is a condition with symptoms or deficits that involve voluntary motor or sensory functions. Though it points to an underlying medical condition, in reality, it arises due to psychological factors. The symptoms are not intentionally produced. Paralysis, blindness, and mutism are the most frequently seen conversion disorder symptoms. 

Option B: Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms. The symptoms are persistent for over 6 months. 

Option C:  Dysthymic disorder is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man has come for a routine medical check-up. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows popcorn calcification (A well-defined round opacity seen at the left upper lung zone) which is suggestive of pulmonary hamartoma.

Pulmonary Hamartoma is the most common benign tumor of the lung and it is manifested by the overgrowth of connective tissue. Pulmonary hamartoma is typically seen in 40-60 years old and is more commonly found in males. 

It is usually discovered as an incidental, rounded coin-like radio-opacity on a routine chest film. Typically solitary, <4 cm, composed of disordered but mature hyaline cartilage, fibrous tissue, smooth muscle, and fat, sometimes with calcification/ossification.  It is usually present peripherally and has slow growth in the lung.

The presence of fat in a well-circumscribed solitary pulmonary nodule which does not demonstrate significant growth is pathognomonic of a pulmonary hamartoma.

questions.text: β HCG is secreted by_____
questions.solution:
The placental gonadotropin in humans is called human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).

  • hCG is a glycoprotein that contains galactose and hexos­amine.
  • It is produced by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta.
  • it is made up of α and β subunits.
  • hCG-α is identical to the α subunit of LH, FSH, and TSH.
  • hCG is primarily luteinizing and luteotropic and has little FSH activity.
  • Its presence in early pregnancy in urine is the basis of the various laboratory tests for pregnancy, and it can sometimes be detected in the urine as early as 14 days after conception.

questions.text: Which of the following will increase the GFR?

choices.text: Decrease in bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.solution:
A decrease in Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure causes an increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

A decrease in Bowman's Capsule Hydrostatic Pressure increases GFR because it reduces the opposing force to filtration, thus enhancing the net filtration pressure and increasing the amount of filtrate formed.

Factors that can increase the GFR are as follows:

  • Increase in glomerular capillary filtration coefficient Kf: This coefficient depends on the hydraulic conductivity and surface area of the glomerular capillaries. 
  • Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Conditions with urinary tract obstruction can lead to an increase in this pressure and a fall in GFR.
  • Decrease in glomerular colloid osmotic pressure: Accumulation of plasma proteins that are not filtered from the blood contributes to this pressure, and an increase reduces further filtration and GFR. It is directly proportional to the following factors: Arterial plasma colloid osmotic pressure.
  • Filtration fraction : An increase in filtration fraction concentrates the plasma proteins and raises the glomerular colloid osmotic pressure which in turn decreases the GFR.

Other options : 

Option A: Efferent Arteriole Dilation reduces the resistance to blood leaving the glomerulus. This leads to a decrease in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure. A reduction in hydrostatic pressure lowers the driving force for filtration, resulting in a decreased GFR.

Option B: Afferent Arteriole Constriction decreases blood flow into the glomerulus. This lowers the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure. Lower pressure reduces the filtration rate across the glomerular capillary wall, leading to a decrease in GFR.

Option C: Increase in Glomerular Plasma Flow: If glomerular plasma flow increases but the efferent arteriole doesn't constrict, the extra blood flow is quickly carried away. This prevents a significant rise in the pressure inside the glomerular capillaries. As a result, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) doesn't significantly increase, because the necessary increase in filtration pressure doesn't occur.

questions.text: A patient presents with photophobia and blurring of vision. On examination, the eye appears as shown below.  What is the mainstay of treatment?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of photophobia and blurring of vision along with red-eye and irregularly shaped pupil (image) suggest a diagnosis of uveitis. Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of the treatment of uveitis.

Steroids are the drug of choice in anterior uveitis. They reduce inflammation by their anti-inflammatory effect. 

Cycloplegics like 1% atropine, relieve spasm of the iris sphincter and ciliary muscles. They prevent the formation of synechiae and reduce exudation.

Systemic therapy includes steroids, NSAIDs, and immunosuppressants. 

Immunosuppressants like voclosporin (calcineurin inhibitor), are used in severe cases. They are being studied under a program called LUMINATE.

questions.text: A young female presented with the following findings on the face. Which among the following will not be useful for its treatment?
questions.solution:
The age of the patient and the presence of papules and pustules with an erythematous base on the face are suggestive of acne. All the above agents are useful in the treatment of acne except topical fluocinolone (topical steroid). Corticosteroids may provoke an acneform reaction irrespective of their route of administration.

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. It is commonly seen in teenagers. It can vary from very mild comedonal acne to severe aggressive pustular acne. These eventually may lead to scarring due to sinus formation.

Acne results from the combination of:

  • Increased sebaceous gland activity under the influence of androgens - oily skin
  • Abnormal follicular differentiation with increased keratinization- hypercornification of the duct due to increased IL-1
  • Microbial hypercolonization of the follicular canal leading to its inflammation.

Management-

  • Mild comedonal acne is treated with a topical retinoid. Mild papular and pustular acne is treated with topical retinoid and topical antibiotics.
  • Moderate papular/pustular acne and moderate nodular acne are treated with oral antibiotic + topical retinoid with or without benzoyl peroxide. 
  • Severe nodular and conglobate acne are treated with oral isotretinoin.

Tazarotene is a fourth‐generation retinoid, which is available for the treatment of acne.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the OPD with complaints of frequent fainting and sudden falls while playing. She sometimes falls off while sitting in the classroom hitting her head to the desk. She regains consciousness immediately and resumes her activity, and has normal behavior after such episodes. The girl is otherwise healthy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history is most consistent with atonic seizures. Atonic seizures are characterized by a sudden loss of postural control and there is no postictal confusion.

Options A and D: Absence seizures usually present as blank stares or unresponsiveness for a few seconds. Postural control is not lost during absence seizures.

Option C: The girl regains consciousness immediately and has no associated complaints like sweating, fatigue, or tachycardia. She also resumes her activity after the episodes. Also, there is no precipitating factor that points towards syncope. Hence it is unlikely to be syncope.

questions.text: A young girl was rushed to the emergency room in a delirious state. Her parents reported her to have consumed a wild fruit as shown below while on a camping trip. On examination, photophobia, staggering gait, flushing, and dry mucous membranes are noticed. The pupils are bilaterally dilated. Which of the following plant poisons she may have consumed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing cherry-like fruit is suggestive that the plant poison the patient may have consumed is Atropa belladonna. 

Atropa belladonna is a deliriant poison that acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine.

Clinical manifestations of Atropa belladonna poisoning include: 

  • Fever, flushing, rash
  • Neurological symptoms - delirium, slurred speech, headache, choreoathetosis, myoclonus, visual and auditory hallucinations, convulsions and coma
  • Eye symptoms - photophobia, blurred vision, dilated pupils poorly reactive to light
  • Cardiovascular symptoms - arrhythmia, tachycardia, hypertension
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms - severely dry mouth and throat, decreased bowel sounds, constipation, ileus
  • Renal symptoms - urinary retention

Anticholinergic symptoms include tachycardia, hypertension, flushing, dry mouth, mydriasis and urinary retention.

questions.text: Folate trap occurs due to the deficiency of ______
questions.solution:
Folate trap occurs in the deficiency of Vitamin B12.

The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF(methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by methionine synthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate that cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap.

Folate cycle provides a link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, where vitamin B12 deficiency causes a functional deficiency of folate.

questions.text: What parameter does the yellow color tracing on the monitor shown below represent?
questions.solution:
The yellow color tracing shown in the monitor is capnography.

Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. 

It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism. 

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both the inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:
  • Phase I: exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: Non-sense mutation is seen in _____________.
questions.solution:
Non-sense mutation is seen in β0 thalassemia.

A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. The point mutations within the coding sequences of the DNA (i.e., the region of the DNA that  codes for proteins) are of two types:

  1. Missense mutations
  2. Non-sense mutations

1. Missense mutations: These mutations may involve alteration of a single base in a triplet of bases and lead to the replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product. Because these mutations alter the meaning of the sequence of the encoded protein, they are often referred to as missense mutations.                                                                                                                                                                            Based on the substituted amino acid coded, the missense mutations are again of two types:

a) Conservative missense mutation: The substituted amino acid is biochemically similar to the original. It typically causes little change in the function of the protein.

b) Non-conservative missense mutation: This type of mutation replaces the normal amino acid with a biochemically different one. An example of this type of mutation is sickle-cell anemia, which is characterized by point mutation affecting the β-globin chain of the hemoglobin, where the nucleotide triplet CTC (or GAG in mRNA), which encodes glutamic acid, is changed to CAC (or GUG in mRNA), which encodes valine.

2. Nonsense mutations: It is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon. For example, a point mutation affecting the codon for glutamine (CAG) creates a stop codon (UAG) if U is substituted for C. This change leads to premature termination of β-globin gene translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. The resulting deficiency of β-globin chains can give rise to a severe form of anemia called β0 thalassemia.

The illustration below shows various types of point mutations:

Other options:

  • Option b: The α-thalassemias are caused by inherited deletions that result in the reduced or absent synthesis of α-globin chains.
  • Option c: Sickle-cell anemia is an example of non-conservative missense mutation.
  • Option d: Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid less deformable and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.

questions.text: A young girl is brought by their parents due to concern about her height. On evaluation, growth hormone levels are found to be high, and insulin-like growth factor levels are low. Which among the following is the likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The presence of high GH levels and low insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels point towards Laron dwarfism. 

It is caused by end-organ resistance to growth hormone(GH insensitivity) due to a mutation in the GH receptor. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder with clinical features like those seen in pituitary dwarfism.

Here, growth hormone is produced but is unable to act on the target tissues. Thus, the resting and stimulated GH levels are high and IGF-1 levels are low.

Patients with Laron syndrome present with features such as:

  • Growth failure
  • Small head circumference
  • Characteristic facies with saddle nose and prominent forehead
  • Short limb length compared with trunk
  • Osteopenia
  • Obesity
  • In some cases mild to moderately impaired intellect may be seen

Other options

Option A: In Turner's syndrome, loss of the short arm of the X chromosome is implicated in dwarfism. The short stature occurs due to a state of GH resistance, relative deficiency, and decreased utilization.

Option B: Pituitary dwarfism is a condition with GH deficiency.

Option D: Maternal deprivation dwarfism is due to psychosocial causes such as emotional deprivation and neglect. There is an inadequate response to GH stimulation tests. The mechanism is not fully understood. No history suggestive of disturbed maternal or family relationships rules this out.

questions.text: A young female patient presents with fever, chills, and abdominal pain 2 days after an uneventful vaginal delivery. The patient is diagnosed with postpartum endometritis. Which among the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: Risk of developing this condition is more with vaginal delivery when compared with caesarian section
Prolonged labour is a risk factor for developing this condition
Patients are treated with oral or parenteral antimicrobials

questions.solution:
The single most important risk factor for developing postpartum endometritis is cesarean birth. Hence the statement that the risk of this developing this condition is greater with vaginal delivery is false.

Postpartum endometritis is an infective condition of the genital tract. The majority of the infections are polymicrobial and are caused by the bacteria present in the genital tract. Important conditions increasing the risk of developing endometritis are cesarean section, prolonged labor, and chorioamnionitis. Patients present with symptoms such as fever, abdominal tenderness, and other features of sepsis.

Oral or parenteral antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A middle-aged obese, non-diabetic, non-hypertensive female patient has been diagnosed with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Which of the following drugs can be used as the first-line treatment in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, Alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is the first-line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) for non-diabetic patients.

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be caused due to the effect of toxins (including certain medications), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, Methotrexate, Doxycycline, and l-Asparaginase are other drugs that can cause hepatic steatosis.

Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is characterized by hepatic steatosis which is complicated by histologically evident hepatocyte death and inflammation. Currently, a liver biopsy is the best investigation to establish the diagnosis.

The current approach to NAFLD management focuses on treatment to avoid or decrease the risk factors for NASH (like obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and dyslipidemia).

Alpha-tocopherol or vitamin E is the first-line treatment considered for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Various clinical trials demonstrate that vitamin E is well-tolerated, and shows modest improvements in AST levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH.

  • Vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic NASH patients.
  • Dose: 800 IU/day.

In patients with diabetes who also have NAS1H/NAFLD, the clinician needs. to consider the presence of NASH while selectingoral anti-hypoglycemic agent. GLP—1 agonists and thiazolidinediones, such as pioglitazone, have been shown to improve fibrosis, inflammation, and steatosis.

 Other options : 

Option A: Ursodeoxycholic acid (a bile acid that improves certain cholestatic liver diseases) and omega-3 fatty acids show no histologic benefit in the management of NASH.

Option C: Metformin is not currently recommended as a treatment for NASH (in patients without diabetes) as there is no conclusive evidence of improved hepatic outcomes. 

Option D: N-acetylcysteine(NAC) is a specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning. It has maximum efficacy when given within 8 hours and can be given either via the oral or intravenous route.

questions.text: A young patient presents to you with the following finding. What is the nerve affected?
questions.solution:
The given image shows is that of a claw hand classically seen in case of an ulnar nerve injury.

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals, adductor pollicis, interossei, and hypothenar muscles in the hand. The lumbricals are primarily responsible for the extension at the interphalangeal joints. Therefore, in ulnar nerve palsy, there is clawing of the medial two fingers.

In ulnar nerve palsy, only the medial two fingers develop clawing, while in a combined median and ulnar nerve palsy, all four fingers develop clawing. 

The following tests are done to test the integrity of the ulnar nerve:

  • Egawa's test - In a positive test, due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger is weak.
  • Book test or Froment's sign - The patient is asked to hold a book between the thumb and index finger while the examiner attempt to pull it forcefully. In case of an ulnar nerve injury, the adductor pollicis is paralyzed and the patient attempts to hold the book with the flexor pollicis longus muscle supplied by the median nerve.
  • Card test - In the case of weak palmar interossei, the examiner can pull out the card with ease. 

Other options

Option B - In radial nerve palsy, the patient presents with a wrist drop due to paralyzed wrist extensors. In high lesions, there is sensory loss on the dorsum of the hand over the anatomical stuff box. 

Option C - In median nerve injury, paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle leads to ape thumb deformity. A pointing finger deformity can also be seen due to paralyzed flexors of the fingers.

Option D - Long thoracic nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle. Patients with injury to this nerve present with winging of the scapula.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with diarrhoea and lesion over his neck as shown in the image below. The condition occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
The above history and clinical features suggest niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency.

Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can cause pellagra. Corn/Maize has low levels of niacin and tryptophan. Jowar has high leucine content which inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme in the synthesis of Niacin.

Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis
  • Dementia

The lesion in the neck is characteristic Casal’s necklace pattern, seen in pellagra. The Casal's collar or Casal's necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4).
